metadata.title: Impact of Meteorological factors and population size on the 1 transmission of Micro-size respiratory droplets based Coronavirus: A 2 brief study of highly infected cities in Pakistan

Although our findings suggested 292 strong correlation of COVID-19 epidemic and various meteorological parameters involving 293 extensive data analysis from various cities of Pakistan. Still, current study has certain limitations 294 as we did not consider other factors like personal hygeine, people mobility and endurance that 295 need to be considered in further studies. FIGREF0.text: of coronavirus disease characterized by pneumonia of unexplained 52 etiology was first reported from Wuhan, China in December, 2019 that later spread globally (Li et 53 al., 2020; Zhu et al., 2020). Coronavirus (COVID-19, or 2019-nCoV) epidemic posed huge impact 54 on public health and economy all over the world and has been declared as public health emergency 55 by World Health Organization (WHO) on January 30, 2020 (Rothan and Byrareddy, 2020). Later, 56

FIGREF1.text: al., 2013). Common symptoms of this pandemic include fever, cough, troubled 61 breathing, fatigue, body pain and lesions on patient's lungs (Guan et al., 2020; Song et al., 2020). 62 In severe conditions, patients suffer from viral pneumonia, diarrhea, acute cardiac injury and 63 RNAaemia (Huang et al., 2020). Nevertheless, recently few cases of corona virus have been 64 claimed by Chinese government with no observed clinical symptoms (asymptomatic) of COVID-65 19 on May 18, 2020. 66 This pandemic has wrapped whole globe and effected 216 countries including Pakistan. In 67 Pakistan, first 2 cases of Corona virus were confirmed by Federal Health Minister of Pakistan on 68 Feb 26, 2020 in Islamabad and Karachi that arrived to twenty (14 in Sindh, 5 in Gilgit Baltistan, 1 69 in Baluchistan in 12 yr. old boy) till March 12, 2020. History of these patients depicts their recent 70 visit to Iran, London or Syria (Ali, 2020; Saqlain et al., 2020). Pakistan share borders with 71 countries infected with COVID-19 namely, China, and Iran (Remuzzi and Remuzzi, 2020; Zhu et 72 al., 2020). First coronavirus death from Pakistan was reported in Peshawar on March 18, 2020. Up 73 to now, a total 1,372,825 tests, 225,282 confirmed cases and 4,619 deaths have been reported by 74 NIH, and more than 54% of total confirmed cases of Pakistan are reported from three highly 75 infected cities such as Karachi (70,143 cases), Lahore (41,416 cases) and Peshawar (11,134 cases) 76 till July 4, 2020. To control this pandemic, the government of Pakistan has taken strict actions like 77 screening of passengers traveling from other countries, restrict inter-city transportation, early 78 detection of new cases, quarantine and restrict people mobility (Noreen et al.). In addition, people 79 are advised to use facemasks, hand sanitizers and maintain a distance of one meter to avoid 80 transmission of virus by direct contact (Organization, 2020; Saqlain et al., 2020). 81 In fact, spread of SARS-CoV-2 is attributed to three different routes of its transmission i.e. (a) 82 Aerosol transmission in confined areas, (b) direct inhalation of large respiratory droplets with 83 diameter ranged 5-10 μm produced by cough or sneeze, (c) Direct contact with surfaces 84 contaminated with virus (Lipsitch et al., 2020). Both, droplet and aerosol are two major routes for 85 transmission of COVID-19 where viral particles spread through breath, sneeze and cough of an 86 infected person. Droplets are large sized mucus or saliva globs (size > 5μm) with virus 87 encapsulated inside that fall in close proximity of their origin while aerosols are comparatively 88

FIGREF2.text: COVID-19 spread (Grayson et al., 2017; Liu et al., 2017), as depicted in Figure 1. Both cough and 90 sneeze emit viral particles in the form of aerosol droplets where cough based particles having 91 diameter < 20 μm quickly loss water and achieve diameter almost less than half of initial size 92 (Nicas et al., 2005). Aerosol can survive in air for long time and can penetrate into alveolar region 93 of lungs causing viral infection deep in alveolar tissues (Tellier, 2009). The distance travel by 94 sneeze and cough based viral particles depends on the speed of droplet clouds, air flow, 95 temperature and humidity of air i.e. larger droplets travel up to 2m (speed 10m/s) from initial point 96 and up to 1m if emitted at speed of 1m/s while sneeze based droplets travel up to 7-8m (Xie et al., 97 2007). In addition, Bioaerosol also known as droplet nuclei have COVID-19 encapsulated inside 98 particles released from expiratory activities of infected person with size in range of 4 to 8 μm (i.e. 99 95% < 100 μm) and their viability lasts for 3 h (Jayaweera et al., 2020). Similarly, droplets of 100 COVID-19 showed trend similar to other SARS viruses in terms of stability and survival on 101 various surfaces where longest duration was reported for glass and plastic surface i.e. 84 h and 72 102 h, respectively while shortest time of droplet's survival is 4 h in case of copper surface (Van 103 Doremalen et al., 2020). Keeping in view its high rate of person to person transmission, series of 104 actions have been recommended by WHO to restrict further spread of COVID-19 (Graham et al., 105 2013; Organization, 2020).

FIGREF4.text: Trajectory of the transmission of COVID-19 by droplets and aerosols from an infected 116 person. 117 Although spread of this viral infection is attributed to public mobility, person to person 118 transmission and through respiratory droplets or direct contact but certain climatic factors also play 119 pivotal role in spread of virus (Chen et al., 2020). Meteorological factors effecting the viability 120 and spread of virus associated respiratory infections like SARS involve ambient temperature, 121 humidity, population size and wind speed as reported by recent epidemiological studies (Dalziel 122 et al., 2018; Ma et al., 2020; Tan et al., 2005). Stability of droplet and survival of coronavirus is 123 dependent on air temperature as well as humidity (Chan et al., 2011). Recently, Tosepu et al., 124 studied correlation of weather parameters and COVID-19 pandemic and reported positive linear 125 correlation between average temperature and cases of COVID-19 in China and Indonesia (Tosepu 126 et al., 2020; Zhu and Xie, 2020). Wang et al. reported effect of temperature on spread and mortality 127 of COVID-19 while Metz and co-workers examined correlation of humidity with survival of virus 128 (Metz and Finn, 2015; Wang et al., 2020). 129 Keeping in view, the significant correlation of climatological conditions with spread of 130 COVID-19, the current study aimed to reveal correlation of COVID-19 pandemic and 131 meteorological parameters including humidity, temperature, rainfall, wind speed and population 132 size. Furthermore, ROC analysis was employed to investigate sensibility and sensitivity of 133 population size, temperature average, temperature minimum, and wind speed on the transmission 134 rate of the novel coronavirus in highly infected cities of Pakistan i.e. Karachi, Lahore and Peshawar 135 to interlink relationship of their effects with COVID-19 mortality.

FIGREF5.text: (of COVID-19 in Pakistan for the period of April 9 to June 9, 2020 was collected 147 from the official website of National Institute of Health (https://www.nih.org.pk/) and daily148 confirmed cases of three highly infected cities (Lahore, Karachi and Peshawar) of Pakistan were 149 gathered from online COVID-19 data archive (https://public.tableau.com/). The location and 150 number of cases of highly infected cities including Lahore, Karachi and Peshawar are shown in 151 Fig. 2A while, the weather data was taken from (https://weatherspark.com/) and 152 (https://www.timeanddate.com/). The targeted climate variables are temperature minimum (˚F), 153 temperature maximum (˚F), temperature average (˚F), humidity (%), rainfall (mm) and windfall 154 (mph). Population data of targeted cities were collect on the official website of Pakistan bureau of 155 statistics (http://www.pbs.gov.pk/).

FIGREF7.text: 161 function. The correlation coefficient values of ±1 represents perfect degree of association between 162 the two variables i.e. values closer to ±1 means stronger correlation while value near 0 means 163 weaker correlation.

FIGREF9.text: 173 employed for comparison between two operating characteristics i.e. true positive rate (TPR) or 174 sensitivity and false positive rate (FPR) or specificity at different threshold settings (Hanley, 1989; 175 Swets, 1979). Area under ROC curve an effective measure of accuracy is employed in current 176 study to confirm correlation of climatic factors including temperature average (TA), temperature 177 minimum (TM), wind speed (WS), and population size (PS) with transmission of COVID-19.

FIGREF10.text: Prism software version 7.0 (GraphPad, Inc., San Diego, CA, USA, www.graphpad.com) 179

FIGREF11.text: Pakistan, first diagnosed case of COVID-19 has been confirmed on February 26, 2020 184 (Waris et al., 2020). A rapid increase in confirmed cases of COVID-19 were observed from March 185 16, 2020 onward, and on July 4, 2020 the total confirmed cases reached 225,282 as shown in Fig. 186 2B. The total number of confirmed cases, deaths and recoveries of three most infected cities such 187

FIGREF12.text: shows the data of COVID-19 cases and climatic factors including temperature average, 189 humidity and wind speed of selected cities. During this observation period (April 9, 2020 to June 190 9, 2020), total number of confirmed cases from selected cities were > 57000 with average daily 191 number as 303. The average daily mean values of climatic factors considered in current study such 192 as temperature minimum, temperature maximum, temperature average, rainfall, humidity average 193 and wind speed were 73.3 ˚F, 92.8 ˚F, 83.0 ˚F, 17.2 mm, 53.6 % and 9.1 mph, respectively.

FIGREF14.text: Daily confirmed cases of COVID-19 with climatic factors (Average temperature, wind 196 speed and average humidity) in Pakistani cities (a) Karachi, (b) Lahore and (c) Peshawar from 197

FIGREF15.text: summarizes the spearman's correlation coefficient between daily COVID-19 199 confirmed cases and climatic variables along with population of selected cities. The result indicates 200 significant correlation of confirmed cases with minimum temperature, average temperature and 201 wind speed for each city while relative humidity is slightly correlated to the cases of Karachi. 202 Finally, as expected, population of each city is strongly correlated with their number of cases. 203 Among selected cities, Karachi is most infected by COVID-19, as assured by resulted statistical 204 relationship of the number of cases with minimum temperature, average temperature, wind speed 205 and population.206

FIGREF16.text: 209ROC analysis was originated in early 1950's and provides an efficient method to evaluate 210 accuracy of a test using intrinsic measures like sensitivity, and specificity. ROC curve (sensitivity211 versus 1-specificity plot) and area under ROC curve represents a reliable tool for performance 212 measurement of test to (i) find out optimal cut off values, and (ii) comparison between alternative 213 diagnostic tasks applied on same subject (Hajian-Tilaki, 2013; Hanley and McNeil, 1982; Hanley 214 and McNeil, 1983). The ROC curve is utilized in current study for sensitivity and specificity 215 analysis over three climatological parameters namely temperature average, temperature minimum 216 and wind speed along with population size in highly effected cities of Pakistan. ROC curves for 217 transmission rate of COVID-19 based on variation in various parameters in selected cities are 218 depicted in Figure 4 where, the design variable is shown on horizontal axis and sensitivity of same 219 variable is represented on vertical axis.

FIGREF18.text: The ROC curve of the transmission rate of COVID-19 based on the various 222 meteorological factors (TM, TA, and WS) and PS in Pakistani cities (a) Karachi, (b) Lahore and 223 (c) Peshawar from April 9, 2020 to June 9, 2020. Specificity represents the true negative rate and 224 sensitivity represents the true positive rate. revealed that both WS and PS model with AUC value 0.9 have high sensitivity and can 226 distinguish positive and negative classes for all selected cities. Similarly, TA and TM models 227 generated for highly effected city i.e. Karachi with AUC value of 0.8 and 0.9, respectively also 228 have good sensitivity and accurately distinguish both classes. In addition, TA and TM models for 229 Lahore (second highly effected city) with AUC value 0.7 has moderate sensitivity while in case of 230Peshawar the generated TA and TM models have worst sensitivity (AUC: 0.5) as given inTable 2312. The nonlinear relationship of TA, TM and PS parameters with number of COVID-19 infected 232 people confirmed sensitivity and direct correlation of COVID-19 transmission with these 233 parameters.

FIGREF19.text: The area under curve of the transmission rate of COVID-19 based on the various 236 meteorological factors and population of selected cities in Pakistan.

FIGREF20.text: investigate the sensitivity of TA, TM, WS and PS on transmission rate of COVID-19 aerosol 243 droplets in highly afflicted cities of Pakistan. Airborne transmission also termed as "droplet based 244 transmission" of infectious agent (i.e. COVID-19) is responsible for unexpected escalation of this 245 epidemic around the globe. Aerosols are liquid or solid particle suspension with virus encapsulated 246 inside and pose high threat towards disease spread (Judson and Munster, 2019; Morawska, 2005). 247 The viability and survival of these viral encapsulated droplets is effected by various environmental 248 factors namely temperature variations, wind speed, humidity, and sunlight. Infectivity of virus (i.e. 249 COVID-19; size< 100 nm) encapsulated aerosols depends mainly on stress caused by temperature 250 along with other environmental factors (Kumar and Morawska, 2020; Marthi, 1994). Association 251 of temperature with spread of viral particles has been extensively reported suggesting direct 252 relation of temperature with viability and infectivity rate of different viral infections. Tan et al., 253 reported higher rate of SARS-CoV cases in places of minimum and ambient temperature zone 254 (Tan et al., 2005). Current study suggested that minimum and average air temperature facilitate 255 the spread and transmission of this SARS-CoV-2 embedded inside aerosol particles and has 256 positive correlation with the increasing number of COVID-19 cases. Our findings are in agreement 257 with the previous reports of (Biswas et al., 2014; Harper, 1961; Shaman and Kohn, 2009; Van 258 Doremalen et al., 2013) suggesting more survival rate of SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV and other 259 influenza virus in low temperature zone and corresponding increase in viral pandemic. Best 260 correlation of temperature minimum and temperature average with number of COVID-19 cases in case of Karachi (highly effected city of Pakistan) where evaporation is an 262 important physiochemical process that affect fate of COVID-19 droplets. Recent studies of Tosepu 263 et al., 2020 support our findings that elucidated the significant correlation between average 264 temperature and COVID-19 cases. Similarly, negative correlation observed in case of rainfall and 265 average humidity in current study are also supported by previous studies of Tan et al 2010 and 266 Metz & Finn et al indicating inverse relation of these variables with number of cases (Metz and 267 Finn, 2015; Tan et al., 2005). Negative correlation observed in case of average humidity in current 268 study is consistent with work reported by Chan et al., 2011 suggesting inverse relation among 269 humidity and SARS coronavirus cases (Chan et al., 2011). Impact of climate on the number of 270 COVID-19 cases in various countries has been reported previously by various research groups to 271 explain the statistical interaction (Bashir et al., 2020; Şahin, 2020; Tosepu et al., 2020; Zhu and 272 Xie, 2020). Furthermore, studies reported over COVID-19 epidemic from China also suggested 273 strong correlation of coronavirus cases and various climatic parameters particularly, temperature 274 and humidity (Sajadi et al., 2020). 275 Wind speed is another important climatic factor that facilitate the spread of infectious diseases like 276 SARS-CoV, COVID-19 and influenza virus (Bashir et al., 2020; Yuan et al., 2006). Positive 277 correlation of wind speed with COVID-19 spread is observed in current study suggesting role of 278 wind for spread of COVID-19 aerosol particles to distance far from their origin. Furthermore, the 279 ROC curve analysis (AUC value range 0.8 to 0.9) also showed good sensitivity of wind speed with 280 number of COVID-19 cases in selected cities of Pakistan. 281 Population size (PS) is reported as major transmittability factor for COVID-19 and showed 282 positive association with COVID-19 epidemic as depicted in Figure 2 while ROC curve analysis 283 also confirmed sensitivity of PS towards spread of COVID-19. These findings are comparable to 284 previous studies of Mehdi et al., that showed strong correlation of PS with number of COVID-19 285 cases (Jahangiri et al., 2020). Role of temperature (i.e. minimum and average), wind speed and 286 population size on COVID-19 spread along with its survival rate and transmission risk on surfaces 287 and air, respectively is well-documented. Therefore, sensitivity analysis of these parameters over 288 transmission rate of COVID-19 in selected cities of Pakistan is crucial for government agencies to 289 devise improved safety measures for survival of people. Owing to significance of PS parameter 290 towards COVID-19 pandemic, more strict actions and control measures are suggested for highly 291 .

FIGREF21.text: COVID-19 droplets and aerosols emitted by cough or sneeze of COVID-19 298 infected person is affected by various environmental factors along with population size. Current 299 study investigated correlation of COVID-19 epidemic with different meteorological parameters 300 particularly, temperature, wind speed, and population size of various cities of Pakistan. Unique 301 characteristics of COVID-19 aerosols being more viable with long survival time in air pose more 302 threat towards its spread. Our findings indicated significant correlation between temperature (i.e. 303 TA and TM) and population size (PS) with COVID-19 pandemic. Furthermore, ROC curves were 304 used to analyze the sensitivity of TA, TM, WS and PS on transmission rate of COVID-19 aerosol 305 particles in highly afflicted cities of Pakistan. The results showed non-linear relationship of TA, 306 TM and PS with number of people effected from COVID-19 in selected cities of Pakistan and 307 sensitivity of all selected parameters with COVID-19 transmission. Results of current study 308 suggest temperature variation and population size as important factors affecting the COVID-19 309 epidemic and can be used by government authorities to devise policy to suppress epidemic thank Dr. Hafiz Muhammad Adnan Hammed and Muhammad Zahid for scientific 313 discussions. Junaid Haider is thankful to "CAS-TWAS President's Fellowship for International 314 PhD Students".
